title.value: The Image Biomarker Standardization Initiative: Standardized Convolutional Filters for Reproducible Radiomics and Enhanced Clinical Insights
title.justification: The title captures the essence of the paper which is about standardizing convolutional filters in radiomics for reproducibility and enhanced insights.
title.quote: The Image Biomarker Standardization Initiative: Standardized convolutional filters for reproducible radiomics and enhanced clinical insights.

extractions.description: The paper discusses the standardization of convolutional filters in radiomics to ensure reproducibility and enhance clinical insights. It presents a study conducted over multiple phases, aimed at establishing reference filtered images and feature values for various convolutional filters. It emphasizes improving the consistency and reliability of radiomics analyses across different imaging modalities.

type.justification: The paper involves an empirical study where experiments were conducted in phases to standardize convolutional filters in radiomics.
type.quote: Here, teams of researchers that developed radiomics software participated in a three-phase study (September 2020 to December 2022) to establish a standardized set of filters.

name.justification: The paper is focused on radiomics, specifically the standardization of convolutional filters used in radiomics analyses.
name.quote: Radiomics involves the high-throughput extraction of quantitative features from medical images to support clinical decision making.

name.justification: The paper deals with medical imaging as it discusses convolutional filters used to enhance patterns and structures in medical images for radiomics.
name.quote: Filters are frequently used in radiomics analyses to enhance and quantify potentially clinically relevant characteristics and textures in medical images.

name.justification: The paper involves techniques such as convolutional filtering, which are also part of the broader field of computer vision.
name.quote: The study attempts to standardize several types of convolution filters (bottom panel).

name.value: The Cancer Imaging Archive Soft-Tissue Sarcoma Dataset
name.justification: This dataset was used for validating the reproducibility of standardized convolutional filters.
name.quote: Validation, reproducibility of standardized convolutional filters was validated on a public dataset of multi-modal imaging (CT, fluorodeoxyglucose-PET, T1-weighted MRI) from 51 patients with soft-tissue sarcoma.

referenced_paper_title.value: The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA): maintaining and operating a public information repository
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the reference paper for TCIA dataset, which provides the soft-tissue sarcoma dataset used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA): maintaining and operating a public information repository. J Digit Imaging. 2013;26(6):1045â€“1057. doi: 10.1007/s10278-013-9622-7.

name.justification: Used to derive reference values for radiomics features during standardized filtering process.
name.quote: Teams computed a filtered image for each configuration from a publicly available chest CT image of a patient with lung cancer

referenced_paper_title.justification: Reference for the use of Radiomics Digital Phantom in the study.
